Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Time-Consistent Risk-Averse Control of Markov Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ruszczynski, 1312016
Dentcheva, 1311978

The project is concerned with optimal control of multi-dimensional dynamic stochastic systems with risk aversion. Two approaches to risk aversion are considered: dynamic risk measures and stochastic orders. The investigators seek to advance their work on risk-averse discrete-time models and to develop general methodology for incorporating risk models into continuous-time optimal control problems of Markov structure. Three major challenges are associated with this project. First, the investigators develop proper mathematical tools for measuring risk in a time-consistent manner that would be suitable for continuous-time Markov systems. Second, the investigators develop optimality theory for control problems involving time-consistent dynamic models of risk. This includes the analysis of the structure of the control models, existence of solutions, and properties of the solutions. When developing risk-averse control models the third challenge has to be taken into account: the possibility to solve the problems numerically in an efficient way.

Decision and control problems under uncertainty arise in many areas: energy production and distribution, telecommunication, insurance and finance, logistics, medicine, security and military applications. In most cases decisions have to be made over time: decisions, as well as the random environment, influence evolution of a system, which creates the need to make new decisions, etc. Therefore, a policy has to be designed that incorporates rules for responding to future states of the system. So far, most theoretical models of such control processes have been based on average performance criteria. The investigators propose to take into account risk, that is, the possibility of occurrence of highly undesirable scenarios. The project develops mathematical models for quantifying risk in dynamical systems that evolve in a continuous way. It also provides methods to determine the best policy, when risk aversion is essential.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main outcomes of the project are mathematical tools to model and control risk in dynamical systems. This research was conducted in three directions.
In joint work with Darinka Dentcheva, time-consistent risk measurement for continuous-time and discrete-space Markov processes has been developed.  By using dual representation of coherent risk measures, new differentiability concepts for multivalued mappings, and a refined concept of time consistency, we developed a system of differential equations that represent dynamic risk measurement. Control of risk amounts to the control of these equations. Another outcome is the construction of close discrete-time approximations to the continuous-time risk measures, which can be used in applications.
In joint work with Jianing Yao, time-consistent dynamic risk theory for controlled diffussion processes has been developed. The resulting risk models reduce to forward-backward systems od stochastic differential equations, which allows for mathematical analysis of the associated control problems and design of control policies. Discretization schemes have been developed and successfully tested on a financial risk control model.
In joint work with Jingnan Fan, risk models have been developed for the case of history-dependent controlled processes in discrete-time. Their special structure has been revealed, and optimization methods designed. Preliminary research on the extension of the theory to partially observable systems has been carried out and methods for finite-state systems developed. The models have been successfully tested on a multistage dynamic investment problem.
In joint work with Curtis McGinity and Darinka Dentcheva, research in risk-averse design of clinical trials has been initiated. We have proposed several risk-averse policies in the framework of approximate dynamic programming. We have identified appropriate features and have tested numerically the performace of the new approach. The effect of using dynamic coherent measures of risk is substantial; it leads to better, much more focused distribution of the medical dose recommendation, at lower loss of human life during the trials.
